17656.text: §¶I am Isaiah, the son of Amoz.¶And this is the message that I was given about Judah and Jerusalem when Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah were the kings of Judah:

17657.text: §¶The Lord has said,/_“Listen, heaven and earth!/The children I raised/_have turned against me.

17658.text: /Oxen and donkeys know/_who owns and feeds them,/but my people won’t ever learn.”

17659.text: ¶Israel, you are a sinful nation/_loaded down with guilt./You are wicked and corrupt/and have turned from the Lord,/_the holy God of Israel.

17660.text: /Why be punished more?/_Why not give up your sin?/Your head is badly bruised,/_and you are weak all over.

17661.text: /From your head to your toes/_there isn’t a healthy spot./Bruises, cuts, and open sores/go without care/_or oil to ease the pain.

17662.text: §¶Your country lies in ruins;/_your towns are in ashes./Foreigners and strangers/take and destroy your land/_while you watch.

17663.text: /Enemies surround Jerusalem,/alone like a hut/in a vineyard/_or in a cucumber field.

17664.text: /Zion would have disappeared/_like Sodom and Gomorrah,/if the Lord All‐Powerful/had not let a few/_of its people survive.

17665.text: §¶You are no better/_than the leaders and people/of Sodom and Gomorrah!/_So listen to the Lord God:

17666.text: /“Your sacrifices/_mean nothing to me./I am sick of your offerings/_of rams and choice cattle;/I don’t like the blood/_of bulls or lambs or goats.

17667.text: ¶“Who asked you to bring all this/when you come to worship me?/_Stay out of my temple!

17668.text: /Your sacrifices are worthless,/_and incense is disgusting./I can’t stand the evil you do/_on your New Moon Festivals/or on your Sabbaths/_and other times of worship.

17669.text: /I hate your New Moon Festivals/_and all others as well./They are a heavy burden/_I am tired of carrying.

17670.text: ¶“No matter how much you pray,/I won’t listen./_You are too violent.

17671.text: /Wash yourselves clean!/I am disgusted/_with your filthy deeds./Stop doing wrong

17672.text: /_and learn to live right./See that justice is done./Defend widows and orphans/_and help those in need.”

17673.text: §¶I, the Lord, invite you/_to come and talk it over./Your sins are scarlet red,/but they will be whiter/_than snow or wool.

17674.text: /If you willingly obey me,/the best crops in the land/_will be yours.

17675.text: /But if you turn against me,/your enemies will kill you./_I, the Lord, have spoken.

17676.text: §¶Jerusalem, you are like/_an unfaithful wife./Once your judges were honest/_and your people lived right;/now you are a city/_full of murderers.

17677.text: /Your silver is fake,/and your wine/_is watered down.

17678.text: /Your leaders have rejected me/_to become friends of crooks;/your rulers are looking/_for gifts and bribes./Widows and orphans/_never get a fair trial.

17679.text: ¶I am the Lord All‐Powerful,/the mighty ruler of Israel,/_and I make you a promise:/You are now my enemy,/and I will show my anger/_by taking revenge on you.

17680.text: /I will punish you terribly/_and burn away everything/that makes you unfit/_to worship me.

17681.text: /Jerusalem, I will choose/judges and advisors/_like those you had before./Your new name will be/_“Justice and Faithfulness.”

17682.text: §¶Jerusalem, you will be saved/_by showing justice;/Zion’s people who turn to me/will be saved/_by doing right.

17683.text: /But those rebellious sinners/who turn against me, the Lord,/_will all disappear.

17684.text: ¶You will be made ashamed/of those groves of trees/_where you worshiped idols.

17685.text: /You will be like a grove of trees/_dying in a drought.

17686.text: /Your strongest leaders/will be like dry wood/_set on fire by their idols./No one will be able to help,/_as they all go up in flames.

17687.text: §¶This is the message that I was given about Judah and Jerusalem:

17688.text: ¶In the future, the mountain/with the Lord’s temple/_will be the highest of all./It will reach above the hills;/_every nation will rush to it.

17689.text: /Many people will come and say,/_“Let’s go to the mountain/of the Lord God of Jacob/_and worship in his temple.”¶The Lord will teach us his Law/from Jerusalem,/_and we will obey him.

17690.text: /He will settle arguments/_between nations./They will pound their swords/and their spears/_into rakes and shovels;/they will never make war/_or attack one another.

17691.text: /People of Israel, let’s live/_by the light of the Lord.

17692.text: §¶Our Lord, you have deserted/_your people, Israel,/because they follow customs/_of nations from the east./They worship Philistine gods/and are close friends/_of foreigners.

17693.text: /They have endless treasures/_of silver and gold;/they have countless horses/_and war chariots.

17694.text: /Everywhere in the country/they worship the idols/_they have made.

17695.text: /And so, all of them/will be ashamed and disgraced./_Don’t help them!

17696.text: §¶Every one of you,/go hide among the rocks/_and in the ground,/because the Lord is fearsome,/_marvelous, and glorious.

17697.text: /When the Lord comes,/everyone who is proud/_will be made humble,/and the Lord alone/_will be honored.

17698.text: /The Lord All‐Powerful/_has chosen a day/when those who are proud/and conceited/_will be put down.

17699.text: ¶The tall and towering/cedars of Lebanon/_will be destroyed./So will the oak trees of Bashan,

17702.text: /all the seagoing ships,/_and every beautiful boat.

17703.text: /When that day comes,/everyone who is proud/_will be put down./Only the Lord will be honored.

17705.text: ¶You had better hide/_in caves and holes—/the Lord will be fearsome,/_marvelous, and glorious/when he comes to terrify/_people on earth.

17706.text: ¶On that day everyone will throw/_to the rats and bats/their idols of silver and gold/_they made to worship.

17707.text: /The Lord will be fearsome,/_marvelous, and glorious/when he comes to terrify/_people on earth—/they will hide in caves/_and in the hills.

17708.text: ¶Stop trusting the power/_of humans./They are all going to die,/_so how can they help?

17709.text: §¶The mighty Lord All‐Powerful/is going to take away/_from Jerusalem and Judah/everything you need—/_your bread and water,

17710.text: /soldiers and heroes,/judges and prophets,/_leaders and army officers,

17711.text: /officials and advisors,/fortunetellers/and others/_who tell the future.

17712.text: /He will let children and babies/_become your rulers.

17713.text: /You will each be cruel/_to friends and neighbors./Young people will insult/_their elders;/no one will show respect/_to those who deserve it.

17714.text: ¶Some of you will grab hold/_of a relative and say,/“You still have a coat./Be our leader/and rule/_this pile of ruins.”

17715.text: /But the answer will be,/“I can’t do you any good./_Don’t make me your leader./There’s no food or clothing/_left in my house.”

17716.text: ¶Jerusalem and Judah,/you rebelled against/_your glorious Lord—/your words and your actions,/_made you stumble and fall.

17717.text: /The look on your faces shows/that you are sinful as Sodom,/_and you don’t try to hide it./You are in for trouble,/and you have brought it all/_on yourselves.

17718.text: §¶Tell those who obey God,/“You’re very fortunate—/_you will be rewarded/_for what you have done.”

17719.text: /Tell those who disobey,/“You’re in big trouble—/_what you did to others/_will come back to you.”

17720.text: /Though you are God’s people,/you are ruled and abused/_by women and children./You are confused by leaders/who guide you/_down the wrong path.

17721.text: ¶The Lord is ready to accuse/_and judge all nations.

17722.text: /He will even judge/you rulers and leaders/_of his own nation./You destroyed his vineyard/and filled your houses/_by robbing the poor.

17723.text: /The Lord All‐Powerful says,/“You have crushed my people/_and rubbed in the dirt/_the faces of the poor.”

17724.text: §¶The Lord says:/_The women of Jerusalem/are proud/and strut around,/_winking shamelessly./They wear anklets that jingle/and call attention/_to the way they walk.

17725.text: /But I, the Lord, will cover/_their heads with sores,/and I will uncover/_their private parts.

17726.text: ¶When that day comes, I will take away from those women all the fine jewelry they wear on their ankles, heads, necks, ears, arms, noses, fingers, and on their clothes. I will remove their veils, their belts, their perfume, their magic charms, their royal robes, and all their fancy dresses, hats, and purses.

17732.text: ¶In place of perfume,/_there will be a stink;/in place of belts,/_there will be ropes;/in place of fancy hairdos,/_they will have bald heads./Instead of expensive clothes,/_they will wear sackcloth;/instead of beauty,/_they will have ugly scars.

17733.text: /The fighting men of Jerusalem/_will be killed in battle.

17734.text: /The city will mourn/and sit in the dirt,/_emptied of its people.

17735.text: ¶When this happens, seven women will grab the same man, and each of them will say, “I’ll buy my own food and clothes! Just marry me and take away my disgrace.”

17736.text: §¶The time is coming when the Lord will make his land fruitful and glorious again, and the people of Israel who survive will take great pride in what the land produces.

17737.text: Everyone who is left alive in Jerusalem will be called special,

17738.text: after the Lord sends a fiery judgment to clean the city and its people of their violent deeds.

17739.text: ¶Then the Lord will cover the whole city and its meeting places with a thick cloud each day and with a flaming fire each night. God’s own glory will be like a huge tent that covers everything.

17740.text: It will provide shade from the heat of the sun and a place of shelter and protection from storms and rain.

17741.text: §¶The Lord said:¶▼I will sing a song/_about my friend’s vineyard/that was on the side/_of a fertile hill.

17742.text: /My friend dug the ground,/removed the stones,/_and planted the best vines./He built a watchtower/and dug a pit in rocky ground/_for pressing the grapes./He hoped they would be sweet,/but bitter grapes/_were all it produced.

17743.text: ¶Listen, people of Jerusalem/_and of Judah!/You be the judge of me/_and my vineyard.

17744.text: /What more could I have done/_for my vineyard?/I hoped for sweet grapes,/but bitter grapes/_were all that grew.

17745.text: ¶Now I will let you know/_what I am going to do./I will cut down the hedge/_and tear down the wall./My vineyard will be trampled/_and left in ruins.

17746.text: /It will turn into a desert,/_neither pruned nor hoed;/it will be covered/_with thorns and briars./I will command the clouds/_not to send rain.

17747.text: ¶I am the Lord All‐Powerful!/_Israel is the vineyard,/and Judah is the garden/_I tended with care./I had hoped for honesty/_and for justice,/but dishonesty/and cries for mercy/_were all I found.

17748.text: §¶You are in for trouble! You take over house after house and field after field, until there is no room left for anyone else in all the land.

17749.text: But the Lord All‐Powerful has made this promise to me:¶Those large and beautiful homes will be left empty, with no one to take care of them.

17750.text: Ten acres of grapevines will produce only six gallons of juice, and five bushels of seed will produce merely a half‐bushel of grain.

17751.text: ¶You are in for trouble! You get up early to start drinking, and you keep it up late into the night.

17752.text: At your drinking parties you have the music of stringed instruments, tambourines, and flutes. But you never even think about all the Lord has done,

17753.text: and so his people know nothing about him. That’s why many of you will be dragged off to foreign lands. Your leaders will starve to death, and everyone else will suffer from thirst.

17754.text: ¶The world of the dead has opened its mouth wide and is eagerly waiting for the leaders of Jerusalem and for its noisy crowds, especially for those who take pride in that city.

17755.text: Its citizens have been put down, and its proud people have been brought to shame.

17756.text: But the holy Lord God All‐Powerful is praised, because he has shown who he is by bringing justice.

17757.text: His people will be like sheep grazing in their own pasture, and they will take off what was left by others.

17758.text: ¶You are in for trouble! The lies you tell are like ropes by which you drag along sin and evil.

17759.text: And you say, “Let the holy God of Israel hurry up and do what he has promised, so we can see it for ourselves.”

17760.text: You are headed for trouble! You say wrong is right, darkness is light, and bitter is sweet.

17761.text: ¶You think you are clever and smart.

17762.text: And you are great at drinking and mixing drinks. But you are in for trouble.

17763.text: You accept bribes to let the guilty go free, and you cheat the innocent out of a fair trial.

17764.text: ¶You will go up in flames like straw and hay! You have rejected the teaching of the holy Lord God All‐Powerful of Israel. Now your roots will rot, and your blossoms will turn to dust.

17765.text: ¶You are the Lord’s people, but you made him terribly angry, and he struck you with his mighty arm. Mountains shook, and dead bodies covered the streets like garbage. The Lord is still angry, and he is ready to strike you again.

17766.text: §¶The Lord has signaled for the foreign nations to come and attack you. He has already whistled, and they are coming as fast as they can.

17767.text: None of them are tired. They don’t sleep or get drowsy, and they run without stumbling. Their belts don’t come loose; their sandal straps don’t break.

17768.text: Their arrows are sharp, and their bows are ready. The hoofs of their horses are hard as flint; the wheels of their war chariots turn as fast as a whirlwind.

17769.text: ¶They roar and growl like fierce young lions as they grab their victims and drag them off where no one can rescue them.

17770.text: On the day they attack, they will roar like the ocean. And across the land you will see nothing but darkness and trouble, because the light of day will be covered by thick clouds.

17771.text: §¶In the year that King Uzziah died, I had a vision of the Lord. He was on his throne high above, and his robe filled the temple.

17772.text: Flaming creatures with six wings each were flying over him. They covered their faces with two of their wings and their bodies with two more. They used the other two wings for flying,

17773.text: as they shouted,¶▼“Holy, holy, holy,/_Lord All‐Powerful!/The earth is filled/_with your glory.”

17774.text: ¶As they shouted, the doorposts of the temple shook, and the temple was filled with smoke.

17775.text: Then I cried out, “I’m doomed! Everything I say is sinful, and so are the words of everyone around me. Yet I have seen the King, the Lord All‐Powerful.”

17776.text: ¶One of the flaming creatures flew over to me with a burning coal that it had taken from the altar with a pair of metal tongs.

17777.text: It touched my lips with the hot coal and said, “This has touched your lips. Your sins are forgiven, and you are no longer guilty.”

17778.text: ¶After this, I heard the Lord ask, “Is there anyone I can send? Will someone go for us?”¶“I’ll go,” I answered. “Send me!”

17779.text: ¶Then the Lord told me to go and speak this message to the people:¶▼“You will listen and listen,/_but never understand./You will look and look,/_but never see.”¶►The Lord also said,

17780.text: ¶“Make these people stubborn!/Make them stop up/_their ears,/cover their eyes,/_and fail to understand./Don’t let them turn to me/_and be healed.”

17781.text: ¶Then I asked the Lord, “How long will this last?”¶The Lord answered:¶Until their towns are destroyed and their houses are deserted, until their fields are empty,

17782.text: and I have sent them far away, leaving their land in ruins.

17783.text: If only a tenth of the people are left, even they will be destroyed. But just as stumps remain after trees have been cut down, some of my chosen ones will be left.

17784.text: §¶Ahaz, the son of Jotham and the grandson of Uzziah, was king of Judah when King Rezin of Syria and King Pekah son of Remaliah of Israel went to attack Jerusalem. But they were not able to do what they had planned.

17785.text: When news reached the royal palace that Syria had joined forces with Israel, King Ahaz and everyone in Judah were so terrified that they shook like trees in a windstorm.

17786.text: ¶Then the Lord said to me:¶Take your son Shearjashub and go see King Ahaz. You will find him on the road near the cloth makers’ shops at the end of the canal that brings water from the upper pool.

17787.text: Tell Ahaz to stop worrying. There’s no need for him to be afraid of King Rezin and King Pekah. They are very angry, but they are nothing more than a dying fire. Ahaz doesn’t need to fear

17789.text: to invade and defeat Judah and Jerusalem and to let the son of Tabeel be king in his place.

17790.text: ¶I, the Lord, promise that this will never happen.

17791.text: Damascus is just the capital of Syria, and King Rezin rules only in Damascus. Samaria is just the capital of Israel, and King Pekah rules only in Samaria. But in less than sixty‐five years, Israel will be destroyed. And if Ahaz and his officials don’t trust me, they will be defeated.

17793.text: §¶Once again the Lord God spoke to King Ahaz. This time he said,

17794.text: “Ask me for proof that my promise will come true. Ask for something to happen deep in the world of the dead or high in the heavens above.”

17795.text: ¶“No, Lord,” Ahaz answered. “I won’t test you!”

17796.text: ¶Then I said:¶Listen, every one of you in the royal family of David. You have already tried my patience. Now you are trying God’s patience by refusing to ask for proof.

17797.text: But the Lord will still give you proof. A virgin is pregnant; she will have a son and will name him Immanuel.

17798.text: Even before the boy is old enough to know how to choose between right and wrong, he will eat yogurt and honey, and the countries of the two kings you fear will be destroyed.

17800.text: But the Lord will make more trouble for your people and your kingdom than any of you have known since Israel broke away from Judah. He will even bring the king of Assyria to attack you.

17801.text: §¶When that time comes, the Lord will whistle, and armies will come from Egypt like flies and from Assyria like bees.

17802.text: They will settle everywhere—in the deep valleys and between the rocks, on every bush and all over the pastureland.

17803.text: ¶The Lord will pay the king of Assyria to bring a razor from across the Euphrates River and shave your head and every hair on your body, including your beard.

17804.text: ¶No one will have more than one young cow and two sheep,

17805.text: but those who do will have enough milk to make yogurt. In fact, everyone left in the land will eat yogurt and honey.

17806.text: ¶Vineyards that had a thousand vines and were worth a thousand pieces of silver will turn into thorn patches.

17807.text: You will go there to hunt with your bow and arrows, because the whole country will be covered with thornbushes.

17808.text: The hills where you once planted crops will be overgrown with thorns and thistles. You will be afraid to go there, and your cattle, sheep, and goats will be turned loose on those hills.

17809.text: §¶The Lord said, “Isaiah, get something to write on. Then write in big clear letters the name, ｟Maher｠‐｟Shalal｠‐｟Hash｠‐｟Baz｠.

17810.text: I will have Uriah the priest and Zechariah son of Jeberechiah serve as witnesses to this.”

17811.text: ¶Sometime later, my wife and I had a son, and the Lord said, “Name him Maher‐Shalal‐Hash‐Baz.

17812.text: Because before he can say ‘Mommy’ or ‘Daddy’, the king of Assyria will attack and take everything of value from Damascus and Samaria.”

17813.text: ¶The Lord spoke to me again and said:

17814.text: ¶These people have refused the gentle waters of Shiloah and have gladly gone over to the side of King Rezin and King Pekah.

17815.text: Now I will send the king of Assyria against them with his powerful army, which will attack like the mighty Euphrates River overflowing its banks.

17816.text: Enemy soldiers will cover Judah like a flood reaching up to your neck.¶▼But God is with us./_He will spread his wings/_and protect our land.

17817.text: /All of you foreign nations,/_go ahead and prepare for war,/_but you will be crushed.

17818.text: /Get together and make plans,/_but you will fail/_because God is with us.

17819.text: ¶The Lord took hold of me with his powerful hand and said:¶I’m warning you! Don’t act like these people.

17820.text: Don’t call something a rebellious plot, just because they do, and don’t be afraid of something, just because they are.

17821.text: I am the one you should fear and respect. I am the holy God, the Lord All‐Powerful!

17822.text: Run to me for protection. I am a rock that will make both Judah and Israel stumble and break their bones. I am a trap that will catch the people of Jerusalem—they will be captured and dragged away.

17824.text: §¶My message and my teachings are to be sealed and given to my followers.

17825.text: Meanwhile, I patiently trust the Lord, even though he is no longer pleased with Israel.

17826.text: My children and I are warning signs to Israel from the Lord All‐Powerful, who lives on Mount Zion.

17827.text: ¶Someone may say to you, “Go to the fortunetellers who make soft chirping sounds or ask the spirits of the dead. After all, a nation ought to be able to ask its own gods

17828.text: what it should do.”¶None of those who talk like that will live to see the light of day!

17829.text: They will go around in great pain and will become so hungry that they will angrily curse their king and their gods. And when they try to find help in heaven

17830.text: and on earth, they will find only trouble and darkness, terrible trouble and deepest darkness.

17831.text: ¶But those who have suffered will no longer be in pain. The territories of Zebulun and Naphtali in Galilee were once hated. But this land of the Gentiles across the Jordan River and along the Mediterranean Sea will be greatly respected.

17832.text: §¶Those who walked in the dark/_have seen a bright light./And it shines upon everyone/who lives in the land/_of darkest shadows.

17833.text: /Our Lord, you have made/_your nation stronger./Because of you, its people/_are glad and celebrate/like workers at harvest time/or like soldiers dividing up/_what they have taken.

17834.text: ¶You have broken the power/of those who abused/_and enslaved your people./You have rescued them/just as you saved your people/_from Midian.

17835.text: /The boots of marching warriors/and the blood‐stained uniforms/_have been fed to flames/_and eaten by fire.

17836.text: §¶A child has been born for us./We have been given a son/_who will be our ruler./His names will be/Wonderful Advisor/_and Mighty God,/Eternal Father/_and Prince of Peace.

17837.text: /His power will never end;/_peace will last forever./He will rule David’s kingdom/_and make it grow strong./He will always rule/_with honesty and justice./The Lord All‐Powerful/will make certain/_that all of this is done.

17838.text: §¶The Lord had warned the people of Israel,

17839.text: and all of them knew it, including everyone in the capital city of Samaria. But they were proud and stubborn and said,

17840.text: ¶“Houses of brick and sycamore/_have fallen to the ground,/but we will build houses/_with stones and cedar.”

17841.text: ¶The Lord made their enemies attack them.

17842.text: He sent the Arameans from the east and the Philistines from the west, and they swallowed up Israel. But even this did not stop him from being angry, so he kept on punishing them.

17843.text: The people of Israel still did not turn back to the Lord All‐Powerful and worship him.

17844.text: ¶In one day he cut off their head and tail, their leaves and branches.

17845.text: Their rulers and leaders were the head, and the lying prophets were the tail.

17846.text: They had led the nation down the wrong path, and the people were confused.

17847.text: The Lord was angry with his people and kept punishing them, because they had turned against him. They were evil and spoke foolishly. That’s why he did not have pity on their young people or on their widows and orphans.

17848.text: ¶Evil had spread like a raging forest fire sending thornbushes up in smoke.

17849.text: The Lord All‐Powerful was angry and used the people as fuel for a fire that scorched the land. They turned against each other

17850.text: like wild animals attacking and eating everyone around them, even their own relatives. But still they were not satisfied.

17851.text: The tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh turned against each other, then joined forces to attack Judah. But the Lord was still angry and ready to punish the nation even more.

17852.text: ¶You people are in for trouble! You have made cruel and unfair laws

17853.text: that let you cheat the poor and needy and rob widows and orphans.

17854.text: But what will you do when you are fiercely attacked and punished by foreigners? Where will you run for help? Where will you hide your valuables?

17855.text: How will you escape being captured or killed? The Lord is still angry, and he isn’t through with you yet!

17856.text: §¶The Lord says:¶I am furious! And I will use the king of Assyria as a club

17857.text: to beat down you godless people. I am angry with you, and I will send him to attack you. He will take what he wants and walk on you like mud in the streets.

17858.text: He has even bigger plans in mind, because he wants to destroy many nations.

17859.text: ¶The king of Assyria says:¶My army commanders are kings!

17860.text: They have already captured the cities of Calno, Carchemish, Hamath, Arpad, Samaria, and Damascus.

17861.text: The gods of Jerusalem and Samaria are weaker than the gods of those powerful nations. And I will destroy Jerusalem, together with its gods and idols, just as I did Samaria.

17863.text: ¶The Lord will do what he has planned against Jerusalem and Mount Zion. Then he will punish the proud and boastful king of Assyria,

17864.text: who says:¶I did these things by my own power because I am smart and clever. I attacked kings like a wild bull, and I took the land and the treasures of their nations.

17865.text: I have conquered the whole world! And it was easier than taking eggs from an unguarded nest. No one even flapped a wing or made a peep.

17866.text: ¶King of Assyria, can an ax or a saw overpower the one who uses it? Can a wooden pole lift whoever holds it?

17867.text: The mighty Lord All‐Powerful will send a terrible disease to strike down your army, and you will burn with fever under your royal robes.

17868.text: The holy God, who is the light of Israel, will turn into a fire, and in one day you will go up in flames, just like a thornbush.

17869.text: The Lord will make your beautiful forests and fertile fields slowly rot.

17870.text: There will be so few trees that even a young child can count them.

17871.text: §¶A time is coming when the survivors from Israel and Judah will completely depend on the holy Lord of Israel, instead of the nation that defeated them.

17872.text: There were as many people as there are grains of sand along the seashore, but only a few will survive to come back to Israel’s mighty God. This is because he has threatened to destroy their nation, just as they deserve.

17874.text: The Lord All‐Powerful has promised that everyone on this earth will be punished.

17875.text: ¶Now the Lord God All‐Powerful says to his people in Jerusalem:¶The Assyrians will beat you with sticks and abuse you, just as the Egyptians did. But don’t be afraid of them.

17876.text: Soon I will stop being angry with you, and I will punish them for their crimes.

17877.text: I will beat the Assyrians with a whip, as I did the people of Midian near the rock at Oreb. And I will show the same mighty power that I used when I made a path through the sea in Egypt.

17878.text: Then they will no longer rule your nation. All will go well for you, and your burden will be lifted.

17879.text: ¶Enemy troops have reached the town of Aiath. They have gone through Migron, and they stored their supplies at Michmash,

17880.text: before crossing the valley and spending the night at Geba. The people of Ramah are terrified; everyone in Gibeah, the hometown of Saul, has run away.

17881.text: Loud crying can be heard in the towns of Gallim, Laishah, and sorrowful Anathoth.

17882.text: No one is left in Madmenah or Gebim.

17883.text: Today the enemy will camp at Nob and shake a threatening fist at Mount Zion in Jerusalem.

17884.text: ¶But the Lord All‐Powerful/_will use his fearsome might/to bring down the tallest trees/_and chop off every branch.

17885.text: /With an ax, the glorious Lord/will destroy every tree/_in the forests of Lebanon.

17886.text: §¶Like a branch that sprouts/_from a stump,/someone from David’s family/_will someday be king.

17887.text: /The Spirit of the Lord/_will be with him/to give him understanding,/_wisdom, and insight./He will be powerful,/and he will know/_and honor the Lord.

17888.text: /His greatest joy will be/_to obey the Lord.¶This king won’t judge/by appearances/_or listen to rumors.

17889.text: /The poor and the needy/will be treated with fairness/_and with justice./His word will be law/_everywhere in the land,/and criminals/_will be put to death.

17890.text: /Honesty and fairness/_will be his royal robes.

17891.text: ¶Leopards will lie down/_with young goats,/and wolves will rest/_with lambs./Calves and lions/_will eat together/and be cared for/_by little children.

17892.text: /Cows and bears will share/_the same pasture;/their young will rest/_side by side./Lions and oxen/_will both eat straw.

17893.text: ¶Little children will play/_near snake holes./They will stick their hands/into dens of poisonous snakes/_and never be hurt.

17894.text: ¶Nothing harmful will take place/_on the Lord’s holy mountain./Just as water fills the sea,/_the land will be filled/with people/who know/_and honor the Lord.

17895.text: §¶The time is coming when one of David’s descendants will be the signal for the people of all nations to come together. They will follow his advice, and his own nation will become famous.

17896.text: ¶When that day comes, the Lord will again reach out his mighty arm and bring home his people who have survived in Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Ethiopia, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, and the land along the coast.

17897.text: He will give a signal to the nations, and he will bring together the refugees from Judah and Israel, who have been scattered all over the earth.

17898.text: Israel will stop being jealous of Judah, and Judah will no longer be the enemy of Israel.

17899.text: Instead, they will get together and attack the Philistines in the west. Then they will defeat the Edomites, the Moabites, and the Ammonites in the east. They will rule those people and take from them whatever they want.

17900.text: ¶The Lord will dry up the arm of the Red Sea near Egypt, and he will send a scorching wind to divide the Euphrates River into seven streams that anyone can step across.

17901.text: Then for his people who survive, there will be a good road from Assyria, just as there was a good road for their ancestors when they left Egypt.

17902.text: §¶At that time you will say,/“I thank you, Lord!/_You were angry with me,/but you stopped being angry/_and gave me comfort.

17903.text: /I trust you to save me,/Lord God,/_and I won’t be afraid./My power and my strength/come from you,/_and you have saved me.”

17904.text: ¶With great joy, you people/will get water/_from the well of victory.

17905.text: /At that time you will say,/“Our Lord, we are thankful,/_and we worship only you./We will tell the nations/how glorious you are/_and what you have done.

17906.text: /Because of your wonderful deeds/we will sing your praises/_everywhere on earth.”

17907.text: ¶Sing, people of Zion!/Celebrate the greatness/_of the holy Lord of Israel./God is here to help you.

17908.text: §¶This is the message that I was given about Babylon:

17909.text: ¶From high on a barren hill/give a signal, shout the orders,/_and point the way/to enter the gates/_of Babylon’s proud rulers.

17910.text: /The Lord has commanded/_his very best warriors/and his proud heroes/_to show how angry he is.

17911.text: ¶Listen to the noisy crowds/_on the mountains!/Kingdoms and nations/_are joining forces./The Lord All‐Powerful/is bringing together/_an army for battle.

17912.text: /From a distant land/the Lord is coming/_fierce and furious—/he brings his weapons/_to destroy the earth.

17913.text: ¶Cry and weep!/_The day is coming/when the mighty Lord/_will bring destruction.

17914.text: /All people will be terrified./Hands will grow limp;/_courage will melt away.

17915.text: /Everyone will tremble with pain/_like a woman giving birth;/they will stare at each other/_with horror on their faces.

17916.text: §¶I, the Lord,/will show no mercy or pity/_when that time comes./In my anger I will destroy/the earth/and every sinner/_who lives on it.

17917.text: /Light will disappear/_from the stars in the sky;/the dawning sun will turn dark,/and the moon/_will lose its glow.

17918.text: ¶I will punish this evil world/and its people/_because of their sins./I will crush the horrible pride/_of those who are cruel.

17919.text: /Survivors will be harder to find/_than the purest gold.

17920.text: /I, the Lord All‐Powerful,/_am terribly angry—/I will make the sky tremble/_and the earth shake loose.

17921.text: ¶Everyone will run/_to their homelands,/just as hunted deer run,/and sheep scatter/_when they have no shepherd.

17922.text: /Those who are captured/_will be killed by a sword.

17923.text: /They will see their children/_beaten against rocks,/their homes robbed,/_and their wives abused.

17924.text: ¶The Medes can’t be bought off/_with silver or gold,/and I’m sending them/_to attack Babylonia.

17925.text: /Their arrows will slaughter/_the young men;/no pity will be shown/_to babies and children.

17926.text: §¶The city of Babylon/is glorious and powerful,/_the pride of the nation./But it will be like the cities/_of Sodom and Gomorrah/after I, the Lord,/_destroyed them.

17927.text: /No one will live in Babylon./Even nomads won’t camp nearby,/_and shepherds won’t let/_their sheep rest there.

17928.text: /Only desert creatures,/_hoot owls, and ostriches/will live in its ruins,/_and goats will leap about.

17929.text: /Hyenas and wolves will howl/from Babylon’s fortresses/_and beautiful palaces./Its time is almost up!

17930.text: §¶The Lord will have mercy on Israel and will let them be his chosen people once again. He will bring them back to their own land, and foreigners will join them as part of Israel.

17931.text: Other nations will lead them home, and Israel will make slaves of them in the land that belongs to the Lord. Israel will rule over those who once governed and mistreated them.

17932.text: §¶The Lord will set you free from your sorrow, suffering, and slavery.

17933.text: Then you will make fun of the King of Babylonia by singing this song:¶▼That cruel monster is done for!/_He won’t attack us again.

17934.text: /The Lord has crushed the power/_of those evil kings,

17935.text: /who were furious/and never stopped abusing/_the people of other nations.

17936.text: ¶Now all the world is at peace;/its people are celebrating/_with joyful songs.

17937.text: /King of Babylonia,/_even the cypress trees/and the cedars of Lebanon/_celebrate and say,/“Since you were put down,/no one comes along/_to chop us down.”

17938.text: ¶The world of the dead/_eagerly waits for you./With great excitement,/the spirits of ancient rulers/_hear about your coming.

17939.text: /Each one of them will say,/“Now you are just as weak/_as any of us!

17940.text: /Your pride and your music/have ended here/_in the world of the dead./Worms are your blanket,/_maggots are your bed.”

17941.text: ¶You, the bright morning star,/_have fallen from the sky!/You brought down other nations;/_now you are brought down.

17942.text: /You said to yourself,/_“I’ll climb to heaven/and place my throne/_above the highest stars./I’ll sit there with the gods/_far away in the north.

17943.text: /I’ll be above the clouds,/_just like God Most High.”

17944.text: ¶But now you are deep/_in the world of the dead.

17945.text: /Those who see you will stare/_and wonder,/“Is this the man/who made the world tremble/_and shook up kingdoms?

17946.text: /Did he capture every city/_and make earth a desert?/Is he the one who refused/_to let prisoners go home?”

17947.text: ¶When kings die, they are buried/_in glorious tombs.

17948.text: /But you will be left unburied,/just another dead body/_lying underfoot/_like a broken branch./You will be one of many/killed in battle/and gone down/_to the deep rocky pit.

17949.text: /You won’t be buried with kings;/you ruined your country/_and murdered your people.¶You evil monster!/We hope that your family/_will be forgotten forever.

17950.text: /We will slaughter your sons/to make them pay/for the crimes/_of their ancestors./They won’t take over the world/or build cities/_anywhere on this earth.

17951.text: ¶The Lord All‐Powerful has promised to attack Babylonia and destroy everyone there, so that none of them will ever be remembered again.

17952.text: The Lord will sweep out the people, and the land will become a swamp for wild animals.

17953.text: §¶The Lord All‐Powerful/_has made this promise:/Everything I have planned/_will happen just as I said.

17954.text: /I will wipe out every Assyrian/_in my country,/and I will crush those/_on my mountains./I will free my people/from slavery/_to the Assyrians.

17955.text: /I have planned this/_for the whole world,/and my mighty arm/_controls every nation.

17956.text: /I, the Lord All‐Powerful,/have made these plans./_No one can stop me now!

17957.text: §¶This message came from the Lord/_in the year King Ahaz died:

17958.text: /Philistines, don’t be happy/_just because the rod/that punished you/_is broken./That rod will become/a poisonous snake,/and then/_a flying fiery dragon.

17959.text: ¶The poor and needy will find/pastures for their sheep/_and will live in safety./But I will starve some of you,/_and others will be killed.

17960.text: ¶Cry and weep in the gates/of your towns,/_you Philistines!/Smoke blows in from the north,/_and every soldier is ready.

17961.text: /If a messenger comes/from a distant nation,/_you must say:/“The Lord built Zion./Even the poorest of his people/_will find safety there.”

17962.text: §¶This is a message about Moab:¶▼The towns of Ar and Kir/were destroyed in a night./_Moab is left in ruins!

17963.text: /Everyone in Dibon has gone up/to the temple and the shrines/_to cry and weep./All of Moab is crying./Heads and beards are shaved/_because of what happened/_at Nebo and Medeba.

17964.text: /In the towns and at home,/everyone wears sackcloth/_and cries loud and long.

17965.text: /From Heshbon and Elealeh,/_weeping is heard in Jahaz;/Moab’s warriors scream/_while trembling with fear.

17966.text: §¶I pity Moab!/Its people are running to Zoar/_and to Eglath‐Shelishiyah./They cry on their way up/_to the town of Luhith;/on the road to Horonaim/_they tell of disasters.

17967.text: /The streams of Nimrim/and the grasslands/_have dried up./Every plant is parched.

17968.text: ¶The people of Moab are leaving,/_crossing over Willow Creek,/taking everything they own/_and have worked for.

17969.text: /In the towns of Eglaim/_and of Beerelim/and everywhere else in Moab/_mournful cries are heard.

17970.text: /The streams near Dimon/_are flowing with blood./But the Lord will bring/_even worse trouble to Dimon,/because all in Moab who escape/_will be attacked by lions.

17971.text: §¶Send lambs as gifts/_to the ruler of the land./Send them across the desert/_from Sela to Mount Zion.

17972.text: /The women of Moab/_crossing the Arnon River/are like a flock of birds/_scattered from their nests.

17973.text: /Moab’s messengers say/_to the people of Judah,/“Be kind and help us!/Shade us from the heat/_of the noonday sun./Hide our refugees!/_Don’t turn them away.

17974.text: /Let our people live/in your country/_and find safety here.”¶Moab, your cruel enemies/_will disappear;/they will no longer attack/_and destroy your land.

17975.text: /Then a kingdom of love/_will be set up,/and someone from David’s family/_will rule with fairness./He will do what is right/_and quickly bring justice.

17976.text: §¶We have heard of Moab’s pride./Its people strut and boast,/_but without reason.

17977.text: /Tell everyone in Moab/_to mourn for their nation./Tell them to cry and weep/for those fancy raisins/_of Kir‐Hareseth.

17978.text: ¶Vineyards near Heshbon/and Sibmah/_have turned brown./The rulers of nations/_used to get drunk/on wine/from those vineyards/_that spread to Jazer,/then across the desert/_and beyond the sea.

17979.text: ¶Now I mourn like Jazer/for the vineyards/_of Sibmah./I shed tears for Heshbon/_and for Elealeh./There will be no more/_harvest celebrations

17980.text: /or joyful and happy times,/_while bringing in the crops./Singing and shouting are gone/_from the vineyards./There are no joyful shouts/where grapes were pressed./_God has silenced them all.

17981.text: ¶Deep in my heart I hurt/_for Moab and Kir‐Heres.

17982.text: /It’s useless for Moab’s people/_to wear themselves out/by going to their altars/_to worship and pray.

17983.text: ¶The Lord has already said all of this about Moab.

17984.text: Now he says, “The contract of a hired worker is good for three years, but Moab’s glory and greatness won’t last any longer than that. Only a few of its people will survive, and they will be left helpless.”

17985.text: §¶This is a message about Damascus:¶▼Damascus is doomed!/_It will end up in ruins.

17986.text: /The villages around Aroer/_will be deserted,/with only sheep living there/_and no one to bother them.

17987.text: /Israel will lose its fortresses./The kingdom of Damascus/_will be destroyed;/its survivors will suffer/_the same fate as Israel./The Lord All‐Powerful/_has promised this.

17988.text: §¶When that time comes,/the glorious nation of Israel/_will be brought down;/its prosperous people/_will be skin and bones.

17989.text: /Israel will be like wheat fields/in Rephaim Valley/_picked clean of grain.

17990.text: /It will be like an olive tree/_beaten with a stick,/leaving two or three olives/_or maybe four or five/on the highest/_or most fruitful branches./The Lord God of Israel/_has promised this.

17991.text: ¶At that time the people will turn and trust their Creator, the holy God of Israel.

17992.text: They have built altars and places for burning incense to their goddess Asherah, and they have set up sacred poles for her. But they will stop worshiping at these places.

17993.text: ¶Israel captured powerful cities and chased out the people who lived there. But these cities will lie in ruins, covered over with weeds and underbrush.

17994.text: ¶Israel, you have forgotten/_the God who saves you,/the one who is the mighty rock/_where you find protection./You plant the finest flowers/_to honor a foreign god.

17995.text: /The plants may sprout/and blossom/_that very same morning,/but it will do you no good,/because you will suffer/_endless agony.

17997.text: /But even if they roar/_like a fearsome flood,/God will give the command/_to turn them back./They will be like dust,/_or like a tumbleweed/blowing across the hills/_in a windstorm.

17998.text: /In the evening/_their attack is fierce,/but by morning/_they are destroyed./This is what happens to those/_who raid and rob us.

17999.text: §¶Downstream from Ethiopia/lies the country of Egypt,/_swarming with insects.

18000.text: /Egypt sends messengers/up the Nile River/_on ships made of reeds./Send them fast to Ethiopia,/whose people are tall/_and have smooth skin./Their land is divided by rivers;/they are strong and brutal,/_feared all over the world.

18001.text: ¶Everyone on this earth,/_listen with care!/A signal will be given/on the mountains,/_and you will hear a trumpet.

18002.text: /The Lord said to me,/“I will calmly look down/_from my home above—/as calmly as the sun at noon/or clouds in the heat/_of harvest season.”

18003.text: ¶Before the blossoms/_can turn into grapes,/God will cut off the sprouts/_and hack off the branches.

18004.text: /Ethiopians will be food/for mountain buzzards/_during the summer/and for wild animals/_during the winter.

18005.text: ¶Those Ethiopians are tall and their skin is smooth. They are feared all over the world, because they are strong and brutal. But at that time they will come from their land divided by rivers, and they will bring gifts to the Lord All‐Powerful, who is worshiped on Mount Zion.

18006.text: §¶This is a message about Egypt:¶▼The Lord comes to Egypt,/_riding swiftly on a cloud./The people are weak from fear./Their idols tremble/_as he approaches and says,

18007.text: /“I will punish Egypt/_with civil war—/neighbors, cities, and kingdoms/_will fight each other.

18008.text: ¶“Egypt will be discouraged/_when I confuse their plans./They will try to get advice/_from their idols,/from the spirits of the dead,/_and from fortunetellers.

18009.text: /I will put the Egyptians/under the power of a cruel,/_heartless king./I, the Lord All‐Powerful,/_have promised this.”

18010.text: §¶The Nile River will dry up/_and become parched land.

18011.text: /Its streams will stink,/_Egypt will have no water,/and the reeds and tall grass/_will dry up.

18012.text: /Fields along the Nile/will be completely barren;/_every plant will disappear.

18013.text: ¶Those who fish in the Nile/will be discouraged/_and mourn.

18014.text: /None of the cloth makers/will know what to do,/_and they will turn pale.

18015.text: /Weavers will be confused;/paid workers will cry and mourn.

18016.text: §¶The king’s officials in Zoan/are foolish themselves/_and give stupid advice./How can they say to him,/_“We are very wise,/and our families go back/_to kings of long ago?”

18017.text: /Where are those wise men now?/_If they can, let them say/what the Lord All‐Powerful/_intends for Egypt.

18018.text: ¶The royal officials in Zoan/and in Memphis/_are foolish and deceived./The leaders in every state/have given bad advice/_to the nation.

18019.text: /The Lord has confused Egypt;/its leaders have made it stagger/_and vomit like a drunkard.

18020.text: /No one in Egypt can do a thing,/_no matter who they are.

18021.text: ¶When the Lord All‐Powerful punishes Egypt with his mighty arm, the Egyptians will become terribly weak and will tremble with fear.

18022.text: They will be so terrified of Judah that they will be frightened by the very mention of its name. This will happen because of what the Lord All‐Powerful is planning against Egypt.

18023.text: §¶The time is coming when Hebrew will be spoken in five Egyptian cities, and their people will become followers of the Lord. One of these cities will be called City of the Sun.

18024.text: ¶In the heart of Egypt an altar will be set up for the Lord; at its border a shrine will be built to honor him.

18025.text: These will remind the Egyptians that the Lord All‐Powerful is with them. And when they are in trouble and ask for help, he will send someone to rescue them from their enemies.

18026.text: The Lord will show the Egyptians who he is, and they will know and worship the Lord. They will bring him sacrifices and offerings, and they will keep their promises to him.

18027.text: After the Lord has punished Egypt, the people will turn to him. Then he will answer their prayers, and the Egyptians will be healed.

18028.text: ¶At that time a good road will run from Egypt to Assyria. The Egyptians and the Assyrians will travel back and forth from Egypt to Assyria, and they will worship together.

18029.text: Israel will join with these two countries. They will be a blessing to everyone on earth,

18030.text: then the Lord All‐Powerful will bless them by saying,¶▼“The Egyptians are my people./I created the Assyrians/_and chose the Israelites.”

18031.text: §¶King Sargon of Assyria gave orders for his army commander to capture the city of Ashdod.

18032.text: About this same time the Lord had told me, “Isaiah, take off everything, including your sandals!” I did this and went around naked and barefoot

18033.text: for three years.¶Then the Lord said:¶What Isaiah has done is a warning to Egypt and Ethiopia.

18034.text: Everyone in these two countries will be led away naked and barefoot by the king of Assyria. Young or old, they will be taken prisoner, and Egypt will be disgraced.

18035.text: They will be confused and frustrated, because they depended on Ethiopia and bragged about Egypt.

18036.text: When this happens, the people who live along the coast will say, “Look what happened to them! We ran to them for safety, hoping they would protect us from the king of Assyria. But now, there is no escape for us.”

18037.text: §¶This is a message about a desert beside the sea:¶▼Enemies from a hostile nation/attack/like a whirlwind/_from the Southern Desert.

18038.text: /What a horrible vision/_was shown to me—/a vision of betrayal/_and destruction./Tell Elam and Media/to surround/and attack/_the Babylonians./The Lord has sworn to end/_the suffering they caused.

18039.text: ¶I’m in terrible pain/_like a woman giving birth./I’m shocked and hurt so much/_that I can’t hear or see.

18040.text: /My head spins; I’m horrified!/Early evening, my favorite time,/_has become a nightmare.

18041.text: ¶In Babylon the high officials/_were having a feast./They were eating and drinking,/_when someone shouted,/“Officers, take your places!/_Grab your shields.”

18042.text: ¶The Lord said to me,/“Send guards/to find out/_what’s going on.

18043.text: /When they see cavalry troops/_and columns of soldiers/on donkeys and camels,/_tell them to be ready!”

18044.text: ¶Then a guard said,/“I have stood day and night/_on this watchtower, Lord.

18045.text: /Now I see column after column/_of cavalry troops.”¶Right away someone shouted,/_“Babylon has fallen!/Every idol in the city/_lies broken on the ground.”

18046.text: ¶Then I said, “My people,/_you have suffered terribly,/but I have a message for you/from the Lord All‐Powerful,/_the God of Israel.”

18047.text: §¶This is a message about Dumah:/From the country of Seir,/_someone shouts to me,/“Guard, how much longer/_before daylight?”

18048.text: ¶From my guard post, I answered,/“Morning will soon be here,/_but night will return./If you want to know more,/_come back later.”

18049.text: ¶This is a message for Arabs/who live in the barren desert/_in the region of Dedan:/You must order your caravans

18050.text: /to bring water for those/_who are thirsty./You people of Tema/must bring food/_for the hungry refugees.

18051.text: /They are worn out and weary/from being chased by enemies/_with swords and arrows.

18052.text: ¶The Lord said to me:¶A year from now the glory of the people of Kedar will all come to an end, just as a worker’s contract ends after a year.

18053.text: Only a few of their warriors will be left with bows and arrows. This is a promise that I, the Lord God of Israel, have made.

18054.text: §¶This is a message/_about Vision Valley:/Why are you celebrating/on the flat roofs/_of your houses?

18055.text: /Your city is filled/_with noisy shouts./Those who lie drunk/in your streets/_were not killed in battle.

18056.text: /Your leaders ran away,/but they were captured/_without a fight./No matter how far they ran,/_they were found and caught.

18057.text: ¶Then I said, “Leave me alone!/_Let me cry bitter tears./My people have been destroyed,/_so don’t try to comfort me.”

18058.text: ¶The Lord All‐Powerful/_had chosen a time/for noisy shouts and confusion/_to fill Vision Valley,/and for everyone to beg/_the mountains for help.

18059.text: /The people of Elam and Kir/attacked with chariots/_and carried shields.

18060.text: /Your most beautiful valleys/_were covered with chariots;/your cities were surrounded/by cavalry troops.

18061.text: /_Judah was left defenseless.¶►At that time you trusted in the weapons you had stored in Forest Palace.

18062.text: You saw the holes in the outer wall of Jerusalem, and you brought water from the lower pool.

18063.text: You counted the houses in Jerusalem and tore down some of them, so you could get stones to repair the city wall.

18064.text: Then you built a large tank between the walls to store the water. But you refused to trust the God who planned this long ago and made it happen.

18065.text: §¶When all of this happened,/the Lord All‐Powerful told you/_to weep and mourn,/_to shave your heads,/_and wear sackcloth.

18066.text: /But instead, you celebrated/by feasting on beef and lamb/_and by drinking wine,/because you said,/“Let’s eat and drink!/_Tomorrow we may die.”

18067.text: ¶The Lord All‐Powerful/has spoken to me/_this solemn promise:/“I won’t forgive them for this,/_not as long as they live.”

18068.text: §¶The Lord All‐Powerful is sending you with this message for Shebna, the prime minister:

18069.text: ¶Shebna, what gives you the right to have a tomb carved out of rock in this burial place of royalty? None of your relatives are buried here.

18070.text: You may be powerful, but the Lord is about to snatch you up and throw you away.

18071.text: He will roll you into a ball and throw you into a wide open country, where you will die and your chariots will be destroyed. You’re a disgrace to those you serve.

18072.text: ¶The Lord is going to take away your job!

18073.text: He will give your official robes and your authority to his servant Eliakim son of Hilkiah.¶Eliakim will be like a father to the people of Jerusalem and to the royal family of Judah.

18075.text: The Lord will put him in charge of the key that belongs to King David’s family. No one will be able to unlock what he locks, and no one will be able to lock what he unlocks.

18076.text: The Lord will make him as firm in his position as a tent peg hammered in the ground, and Eliakim will bring honor to his family.

18077.text: ¶His children and relatives will be supported by him, like pans hanging from a peg on the wall.

18078.text: That peg is fastened firmly now, but someday it will be shaken loose and fall down. Then everything that was hanging on it will be destroyed. This is what the Lord All‐Powerful has promised.

18079.text: §¶This is a message/from distant islands/_about the city of Tyre:/Cry, you seagoing ships!/Tyre and its houses/_lie in ruins.

18080.text: /Mourn in silence,/you shop owners of Sidon,/_you people on the coast./Your sailors crossed oceans,/_making your city rich.

18081.text: /Your merchants sailed the seas,/making you wealthy/by trading/_with nation after nation./They brought back grain/_that grew along the Nile.

18082.text: /Sidon, you are a mighty fortress/_built along the sea./But you will be disgraced/like a married woman/_who never had children.

18083.text: ¶When Egypt hears about Tyre,/_it will tremble.

18084.text: /All of you along the coast/had better cry/and sail/_far across the ocean.

18085.text: /Can this be the happy city/_that has stood for centuries?/Its people have spread/_to distant lands;

18086.text: /its merchants were kings/_honored all over the world./Who planned to destroy Tyre?

18087.text: /The Lord All‐Powerful planned it/_to bring shame and disgrace/to those/who are honored/_by everyone on earth.

18088.text: /People of Tyre,/_your harbor is destroyed!/You will have to become farmers/_just like the Egyptians.

18089.text: §¶The Lord’s hand has reached/across the sea,/_upsetting the nations./He has given a command/to destroy fortresses/_in the land of Canaan.

18090.text: /The Lord has said/_to the people of Sidon,/“Your celebrating is over—/_you are crushed./Even if you escape to Cyprus,/_you won’t find peace.”

18091.text: ¶Look what the Assyrians have done to Babylonia! They have attacked, destroying every palace in the land. Now wild animals live among the ruins.

18092.text: Not a fortress will be left standing, so tell all the seagoing ships to mourn.

18093.text: ¶The city of Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years, which is the lifetime of a king. Then Tyre will be like that evil woman in the song:

18094.text: ¶You’re gone and forgotten,/_you evil woman!/So strut through the town,/_singing and playing/your favorite tune/_to be remembered again.

18095.text: ¶At the end of those seventy years, the Lord will let Tyre get back into business. The city will be like a woman who sells her body to everyone of every nation on earth,

18096.text: but none of what is earned will be kept in the city. That money will belong to the Lord, and it will be used to buy more than enough food and good clothes for those who worship the Lord.

18097.text: §¶The Lord is going to twist the earth out of shape and turn it into a desert. Everyone will be scattered,

18098.text: including ordinary people and priests, slaves and slave owners, buyers and sellers, lenders and borrowers, the rich and the poor.

18099.text: The earth will be stripped bare and left that way. This is what the Lord has promised.

18100.text: ¶The earth wilts away;/its mighty leaders melt/_to nothing.

18101.text: /The earth is polluted/_because its people/disobeyed the laws of God,/breaking their agreement/_that was to last forever.

18102.text: ¶The earth is under a curse;/its people are dying out/_because of their sins.

18103.text: /Grapevines have dried up:/_wine is almost gone—/mournful sounds are heard/_instead of joyful shouts.

18104.text: ¶No one plays tambourines/_or stringed instruments;/all noisy celebrating/_has come to an end.

18105.text: /They no longer sing/as they drink their wine,/_and it tastes sour.

18106.text: ¶Towns are crushed and in chaos;/_houses are locked tight.

18107.text: /Happy times have disappeared/_from the earth,/and people shout in the streets,/_“We’re out of wine!”

18108.text: /Cities are destroyed;/_their gates are torn down.

18109.text: /Nations will be stripped bare,/like olive trees/or vineyards/_after the harvest season.

18110.text: §¶People in the west shout;/they joyfully praise/_the majesty of the Lord.

18111.text: /And so, everyone in the east/_and those on the islands/should praise the Lord,/_the God of Israel.

18112.text: /From all over the world/songs of praise are heard/_for the God of justice./But I feel awful,/_terribly miserable./Can anyone be trusted?/_So many are treacherous!

18113.text: §¶Terror, traps, and pits/_are waiting for everyone.

18114.text: /If you are terrified and run,/_you will fall into a pit;/if you crawl out of the pit,/_you will get caught in a trap.¶The sky has split apart/_like a window thrown open./The foundations of the earth/_have been shaken;

18116.text: /It staggers and shakes/like a drunkard/_or a hut in a windstorm./It is burdened down with sin;/the earth will fall,/_never again to get up.

18117.text: ¶On that day the Lord/_will punish/the powers/in the heavens/_and the kings of the earth.

18118.text: /He will put them in a pit/_and keep them prisoner./Then later on,/_he will punish them.

18119.text: /The moon and sun will both/_be embarrassed and ashamed./The Lord All‐Powerful will rule/_on Mount Zion in Jerusalem,/where he will show its rulers/_his wonderful glory.

18120.text: §¶You, Lord, are my God!/_I will praise you/for doing the wonderful things/you had planned and promised/_since ancient times.

18121.text: /You have destroyed the fortress/of our enemies,/_leaving their city in ruins./Nothing in that foreign city/_will ever be rebuilt.

18122.text: /Now strong and cruel nations/_will fear and honor you.

18123.text: ¶You have been a place of safety/for the poor and needy/_in times of trouble./Brutal enemies pounded us/_like a heavy rain/or the heat of the sun at noon,/_but you were our shelter.

18124.text: /Those wild foreigners struck/_like scorching desert heat./But you were like a cloud,/_protecting us from the sun./You kept our enemies from singing/_songs of victory.

18125.text: §¶On this mountain/_the Lord All‐Powerful/will prepare/for all nations/_a feast of the finest foods./Choice wines and the best meats/_will be served.

18126.text: /Here the Lord will strip away/the burial clothes/_that cover the nations.

18127.text: /The Lord All‐Powerful/will destroy the power of death/_and wipe away all tears./No longer will his people/be insulted everywhere./_The Lord has spoken!

18128.text: ¶At that time, people will say,/“The Lord has saved us!/_Let’s celebrate./We waited and hoped—/_now our God is here.”

18129.text: /The powerful arm of the Lord/_will protect this mountain.¶The Moabites will be put down/and trampled on like straw/_in a pit of manure.

18130.text: /They will struggle to get out,/but God will humiliate them/_no matter how hard they try.

18131.text: /The walls of their fortresses/will be knocked down/_and scattered in the dirt.

18132.text: §¶The time is coming/when the people of Judah/_will sing this song:/“Our city is protected./The Lord is our fortress,/_and he gives us victory.

18133.text: /Open the city gates/for a law‐abiding nation/_that is faithful to God.

18134.text: /The Lord gives perfect peace/_to those whose faith is firm.

18135.text: /So always trust the Lord/because he is forever/_our mighty rock.

18136.text: /God has put down our enemies/in their mountain city/_and rubbed it in the dirt.

18137.text: /Now the poor and abused/_stomp all over that city.”

18138.text: §¶Our Lord, you always do right,/and you make the path smooth/_for those who obey you.

18139.text: /You are the one we trust/_to bring about justice;/above all else we want/_your name to be honored.

18140.text: /Throughout the night,/_my heart searches for you,/because your decisions/show everyone on this earth/_how to live right.

18141.text: ¶Even when the wicked/are treated with mercy/_in this land of justice,/they do wrong and are blind/_to your glory, our Lord.

18142.text: /Your hand is raised and ready/_to punish them,/but they don’t see it./_Put them to shame!/Show how much you care for us/and throw them into the fire/_intended for your enemies.

18143.text: ¶You will give us peace, Lord,/because everything we have done/_was by your power.

18144.text: /Others have ruled over us/besides you, our Lord God,/_but we obey only you.

18145.text: /Those enemies are now dead/_and can never live again./You have punished them—/they are destroyed,/_completely forgotten.

18146.text: /Our nation has grown/_because of you, our Lord./We have more land than before,/_and you are honored.

18147.text: §¶When you punished our people,/they turned and prayed/_to you, our Lord.

18148.text: /_Because of what you did to us,/we suffered like a woman/_about to give birth.

18149.text: /But instead of having a child,/our terrible pain/_produced only wind./We have won no victories,/and we have no descendants/_to take over the earth.

18150.text: ¶Your people will rise to life!/Tell them to leave their graves/_and celebrate with shouts./You refresh the earth/like morning dew;/_you give life to the dead.

18151.text: ¶Go inside and lock the doors,/_my people./Hide there for a little while,/until the Lord/_is no longer angry.

18152.text: §¶The Lord will come out/to punish everyone on earth/_for their sins./And when he does,/those who did violent crimes/_will be known and punished.

18153.text: /On that day, Leviathan,/_the sea monster,/will squirm and try to escape,/but the Lord will kill him/_with a cruel, sharp sword.

18154.text: §¶The Lord said:¶▼At that time you must sing/_about a fruitful vineyard.

18155.text: /I, the Lord, will protect it/_and always keep it watered./I will guard it day and night/_to keep it from harm.

18156.text: /I am no longer angry./_But if it produces thorns,/I will go to war against it/_and burn it to the ground.

18157.text: /Yet if the vineyard depends/_on me for protection,/it will become my friend/_and be at peace with me.

18158.text: ¶Someday Israel will take root/_like a vine./It will blossom and bear fruit/_that covers the earth.

18159.text: ¶I, the Lord, didn’t punish and kill/_the people of Israel/as fiercely as I punished/_and killed their enemies.

18160.text: /I carefully measured out/_Israel’s punishment/and sent the scorching heat/_to chase them far away.

18161.text: ¶There’s only one way/that Israel’s sin and guilt/_can be completely forgiven:/They must crush the stones/of every pagan altar/_and place of worship.

18162.text: §¶Fortress cities are left/like a desert/_where no one lives./Cattle walk through the ruins,/_stripping the trees bare.

18163.text: /When broken branches/_fall to the ground,/women pick them up/_to feed the fire./But these people are so stupid/that the God who created them/_will show them no mercy.

18164.text: ¶The time is coming when the Lord will shake the land between the Euphrates River and the border of Egypt, and one by one he will bring all of his people together.

18165.text: A loud trumpet will be heard. Then the people of Israel who were dragged away to Assyria and Egypt will return to worship the Lord on his holy mountain in Jerusalem.

18166.text: §¶The city of Samaria/above a fertile valley/_is in for trouble!/Its leaders are drunkards,/who stuff themselves/_with food and wine./But they will be like flowers/_that dry up and wilt.

18167.text: /Only the Lord is strong/_and powerful!/His mighty hand/_will strike them down/with the force of a hailstorm/or a mighty whirlwind/_or an overwhelming flood.

18168.text: ¶Every drunkard in Ephraim/takes pride in Samaria,/_but it will be crushed.

18169.text: /Samaria above a fertile valley/_will quickly lose its glory./It will be gobbled down/like the first ripe fig/_at harvest season.

18170.text: ¶When this time comes,/_the Lord All‐Powerful/will be a glorious crown/_for his people who survive.

18171.text: /He will see that justice rules/and that his people/are able/_to defend their cities.

18172.text: §¶Priests and prophets stumble/_because they are drunk./Their minds are too confused/to receive God’s messages/_or give honest decisions.

18173.text: /Their tables are covered,/completely covered,/_with their stinking vomit.

18174.text: ¶You drunken leaders/_are like babies!/How can you possibly understand/_or teach the Lord’s message?

18175.text: /You don’t even listen—/all you hear is senseless sound/_after senseless sound.

18176.text: ¶So, the Lord will speak/_to his people/in strange sounds/_and foreign languages.

18177.text: /He promised you/perfect peace and rest,/_but you refused to listen.

18178.text: /Now his message to you/will be senseless sound/_after senseless sound./Then you will fall backwards,/_injured and trapped.

18179.text: §¶You rulers of Jerusalem/_do nothing but sneer;/now you must listen/_to what the Lord says.

18180.text: /Do you think you have/an agreement with death/_and the world of the dead?/Why do you trust in your lies/to keep you safe from danger/_and the mighty flood?

18181.text: ¶And so the Lord says,/“I’m laying a firm foundation/_for the city of Zion./It’s a valuable cornerstone/_proven to be trustworthy;/no one who trusts it/_will ever be disappointed.

18182.text: /Justice and fairness/will be the measuring lines/_that help me build.”¶Hailstones and floods/will destroy and wash away/_your shelter of lies.

18183.text: /Your agreement with death/and the world of the dead/_will be broken./Then angry, roaring waves/_will sweep over you.

18184.text: /Morning, noon, and night/an overwhelming flood/_will wash you away./The terrible things that happen/_will teach you this lesson:

18185.text: /Your bed is too short,/_your blanket too skimpy.

18186.text: ¶The Lord will fiercely attack/as he did at Mount Perazim/_and in Gibeon Valley./But this time the Lord/will do something surprising,/_not what you expect.

18187.text: /So you had better stop sneering/or you will be in worse shape/_than ever before./I heard the Lord All‐Powerful/threaten the whole country/_with destruction.

18188.text: §¶Pay close attention/_to what I am saying.

18189.text: /Farmers don’t just plow/_and break up the ground.

18190.text: /When a field is ready,/they scatter the seeds/_of dill and cumin;/they plant the seeds/of wheat and barley/_in the proper places.

18192.text: ¶After dill and cumin/_have been harvested,/the stalks are pounded,/_not run over with a wagon.

18193.text: /Wheat and barley are pounded,/_but not beaten to pulp;/they are run over with a wagon,/_but not ground to dust.

18194.text: /This wonderful knowledge comes/from the Lord All‐Powerful,/_who has such great wisdom.

18195.text: §¶The Lord said:¶▼Jerusalem, city of David,/the place of my altar,/_you are in for trouble!/Celebrate your festivals/_year after year.

18196.text: /I will still make you suffer,/and your people will cry/_when I make an altar of you.

18197.text: /I will surround you and prepare/_to attack from all sides.

18198.text: /From deep in the earth,/you will call out for help/_with only a faint whisper.

18199.text: ¶Then your cruel enemies/will suddenly be swept away/_like dust in a windstorm.

18200.text: /I, the Lord All‐Powerful,/_will come to your rescue/with a thundering earthquake/_and a fiery whirlwind.

18201.text: ¶Every brutal nation/that attacks Jerusalem/_and makes it suffer/will disappear like a dream/_when night is over.

18202.text: /Those nations that attack/_Mount Zion/will suffer from hunger/_and thirst./They will dream of food and drink/but wake up weary and hungry/_and thirsty as ever.

18203.text: §¶Be shocked and stunned,/_you prophets!/Refuse to see./Get drunk and stagger,/_but not from wine.

18204.text: /The Lord has made you drowsy;/he put you into a deep sleep/_and covered your head.

18205.text: ¶Now his message is like a sealed letter to you. Some of you say, “We can’t read it, because it’s sealed.”

18206.text: Others say, “We can’t read it, because we don’t know how to read.”

18207.text: ¶The Lord has said:¶▼“These people praise me/_with their words,/but they never really/_think about me./They worship me by repeating/_rules/made up by humans.

18208.text: /So once again I will do things/_that shock and amaze them,/and I will destroy the wisdom/of those who claim to know/_and understand.”

18209.text: ¶You are in for trouble,/if you try to hide your plans/_from the Lord!/Or if you think what you do/_in the dark can’t be seen.

18210.text: /You have it all backwards./A clay dish doesn’t say/_to the potter,/“You didn’t make me./_You don’t even know how.”

18211.text: §¶Soon the forest of Lebanon/will become a field with crops,/_thick as a forest.

18212.text: /The deaf will be able to hear/_whatever is read to them;/the blind will be freed/_from a life of darkness.

18213.text: /The poor and the needy/_will celebrate and shout/because of the Lord,/_the holy God of Israel.

18214.text: ¶All who are cruel and arrogant/_will be gone forever./Those who live by crime/_will disappear,

18215.text: /together with everyone/_who tells lies in court/and keeps innocent people/_from getting a fair trial.

18216.text: ¶The Lord who rescued Abraham/has this to say/_about Jacob’s descendants:/“They will no longer/_be ashamed and disgraced.

18217.text: /When they see how great/_I have made their nation,/they will praise and honor me,/_the holy God of Israel.

18218.text: /Everyone who is confused/_will understand,/and all who have complained/_will obey my teaching.”

18219.text: §¶This is the Lord’s message for his rebellious people:¶▼“You follow your own plans/_instead of mine;/you make treaties/without asking me,/_and you keep on sinning.

18220.text: /You trust Egypt for protection./_So you refuse my advice/and send messengers to Egypt/_to beg their king for help.

18221.text: ¶You will be disappointed,/completely disgraced/_for trusting Egypt.

18222.text: /The king’s power reaches/from the city of Zoan/_as far south as Hanes.

18223.text: /But Egypt can’t protect you,/and to trust that nation/_is useless and foolish.”

18224.text: ¶This is a message/about the animals/_of the Southern Desert:/You people carry treasures/_on donkeys and camels./You travel to a feeble nation/through a troublesome desert/_filled with lions/_and flying fiery dragons.

18225.text: /Egypt can’t help you!/That’s why I call that nation/_a helpless monster.”

18226.text: §¶The Lord told me to write down his message for his people, so that it would be there forever.

18227.text: They have turned against the Lord and can’t be trusted. They have refused his teaching

18228.text: and have said to his messengers and prophets:¶Don’t tell us what God has shown you and don’t preach the truth. Just say what we want to hear, even if it’s false.

18229.text: Stop telling us what God has said! We don’t want to hear any more about the holy God of Israel.

18230.text: ¶Now this is the answer/_of the holy God of Israel:/“You rejected my message,/and you trust in violence/_and lies.

18231.text: /This sin is like a crack/_that makes a high wall/quickly crumble

18232.text: /and shatter/_like a crushed bowl./There’s not a piece left/big enough to carry hot coals/_or to dip out water.”

18233.text: §¶The holy Lord God of Israel/_had told all of you,/“I will keep you safe/if you turn back to me/_and calm down./I will make you strong/_if you quietly trust me.”¶Then you stubbornly

18234.text: /said,/“No! We will safely escape/_on speedy horses.”¶But those who chase you/_will be even faster.

18235.text: /As few as five of them,/or even one,/will be enough/_to chase a thousand of you./Finally, all that will be left/_will be a few survivors/as lonely as a flag pole/_on a barren hill.

18236.text: §¶The Lord God is waiting/to show how kind he is/_and to have pity on you./The Lord always does right;/he blesses those who trust him.

18237.text: ¶People of Jerusalem, you don’t need to cry anymore. The Lord is kind, and as soon as he hears your cries for help, he will come.

18238.text: The Lord has given you trouble and sorrow as your food and drink. But now you will again see the Lord, your teacher, and he will guide you.

18239.text: Whether you turn to the right or to the left, you will hear a voice saying, “This is the road! Now follow it.”

18240.text: Then you will treat your idols of silver and gold like garbage; you will throw them away like filthy rags.

18241.text: ¶The Lord will send rain to water the seeds you have planted—your fields will produce more crops than you need, and your cattle will graze in open pastures.

18242.text: Even the oxen and donkeys that plow your fields will be fed the finest grain.

18243.text: ¶On that day people will be slaughtered and towers destroyed, but streams of water will flow from high hills and towering mountains.

18244.text: Then the Lord will bandage his people’s injuries and heal the wounds he has caused. The moon will shine as bright as the sun, and the sun will shine seven times brighter than usual. It will be like the light of seven days all at once.

18245.text: §¶The Lord is coming/_from far away/with his fiery anger/_and thick clouds of smoke./His angry words flame up/_like a destructive fire;

18246.text: /he breathes out a flood/_that comes up to the neck./He sifts the nations/_and destroys them./Then he puts a bridle/in every foreigner’s mouth/_and leads them to doom.

18247.text: ¶The Lord’s people will sing as they do when they celebrate a religious festival at night. The Lord is Israel’s mighty rock, and his people will be as happy as they are when they follow the sound of flutes to the mountain where he is worshiped.

18248.text: ¶The Lord will get furious. His fearsome voice will be heard, his arm will be seen ready to strike, and his anger will be like a destructive fire, followed by thunderstorms and hailstones.

18249.text: When the Assyrians hear the Lord’s voice and see him striking with his iron rod, they will be terrified.

18250.text: He will attack them in battle, and each time he strikes them, it will be to the music of tambourines and harps.

18251.text: ¶Long ago the Lord got a place ready for burning the body of the dead king. The place for the fire is deep and wide, the wood is piled high, and the Lord will start the fire by breathing out flaming sulfur.

18252.text: §¶You are in for trouble/_if you go to Egypt for help,/or if you depend on/an army of chariots/_or a powerful cavalry./Instead you should depend on/and trust/the holy Lord God/_of Israel.

18253.text: /The Lord isn’t stupid!/He does what he promises,/_and he can bring doom./If you are cruel yourself,/or help those who are evil,/_you will be destroyed.

18254.text: ¶The Egyptians are mere humans./_They aren’t God./Their horses are made of flesh;/_they can’t live forever./When the Lord shows his power,/he will destroy the Egyptians/_and all who depend on them./Together they will fall.

18255.text: ¶The Lord All‐Powerful/_said to me,/“I will roar and attack/_like a fearless lion/not frightened by the shouts/of shepherds/trying to protect/_their sheep./That’s how I will come down/_and fight on Mount Zion.

18256.text: /I, the Lord All‐Powerful,/_will protect Jerusalem/like a mother bird circling/_over her nest.”

18257.text: §¶People of Israel, come back!/You have completely turned/_from the Lord.

18258.text: /The time is coming/_when you will throw away/your idols of silver and gold,/_made by your sinful hands.

18259.text: ¶The Assyrians will be killed,/but not by the swords/_of humans./Their young men will try/_to escape,/but they will be captured/_and forced into slavery.

18260.text: /Their fortress will fall/_when terror strikes;/their army officers/will be frightened/_and run from the battle./This is what the Lord has said,/the Lord whose fiery furnace/_is built on Mount Zion.

18261.text: §¶A king and his leaders/_will rule with justice.

18262.text: /They will be a place of safety/_from stormy winds,/a stream in the desert,/and a rock that gives shade/_from the heat of the sun.

18263.text: /Then everyone who has eyes/_will open them and see,/and those who have ears/_will pay attention.

18264.text: /All who are impatient/_will take time to think;/everyone who stutters/_will talk clearly.

18265.text: ¶Fools will no longer/_be highly respected,/and crooks won’t be given/_positions of honor.

18266.text: /Fools talk foolishness./They always make plans/_to do sinful things,/_to lie about the Lord,/_to let the hungry starve,/and to keep water/from those/_who are thirsty.

18267.text: /Cruel people tell lies—/they do evil things,/_and make cruel plans/to destroy the poor and needy,/even when they beg/_for justice.

18268.text: /But helpful people/can always be trusted/_to make helpful plans.

18269.text: §¶Listen to what I say,/you women/who are carefree/_and careless!

18270.text: /You may not have worries now,/_but in about a year,/the grape harvest will fail,/_and you will tremble.

18271.text: ¶Shake and shudder,/_you women without a care!/Strip off your clothes—/_put on sackcloth.

18272.text: /Slap your breasts in sorrow/_because of what happened/to the fruitful fields/_and vineyards,

18273.text: /and to the happy homes/_in Jerusalem./The land of my people/_is covered with thorns.

18274.text: ¶The palace will be deserted,/_the crowded city empty./Fortresses and towers/_will forever become/playgrounds for wild donkeys/_and pastures for sheep.

18275.text: §¶When the Spirit is given to us/_from heaven,/deserts will become orchards/_thick as fertile forests.
